AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: The automated agent outputs repetitive/templated content and appears to rely on OCR limitations as a blocker, leading to friction (customer insists the serial is readable). It also repeatedly requests extensive RMA artifacts (video, full details) even when the customer is dealing with a remote outage, which reads as low-adaptiveness and poor prioritization. Some conclusions (e.g., “not an obvious hardware failure”) may be premature given recurring WAN/UI outages on a replacement unit, though this is partially process-driven.
evidence: Customer: "This in unacceptable. The unit is located remote and we cannot drive there every week to do some HW diagnostics tools."
AI Manager (public): "Serial Number ... — the two SN photos were unreadable, so please either type the Serial Number in your message or send a close-up photo"
Customer: "SN is cleary readable from the photo - green sticker. Do you mean something else?"
AI Manager (public): "A video recording depicting the reported behavior ... will be sufficient"

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: There is no clear evidence the customer was unable to reach a human or explicitly requested a human agent. The conversation shows back-and-forth responses and does not show an explicit AI loop preventing escalation to a person.
evidence: ATLAS transcript: "If I'm not able to resolve your issue, I can connect you with one of our support specialists"

IGNORING_CONTEXT.reasoning: Support repeatedly asked for information that was either already provided (license confirmed; later shipping/contact details provided) or available from the prior RMA reference, creating unnecessary repetition. After the customer provided shipping/contact details, internal notes still flagged key address elements as missing (e.g., ZIP), suggesting the process did not adapt to the information already supplied. The serial-number back-and-forth also indicates the agent did not effectively use the provided attachment/context.
evidence: Customer: "I have no idea SN. You can propably find it via last ticket 60235438 where was RMA located."
AI Manager (public): "License key (if it differs from the one on record: 20339-1LKR4-8WJVB)"
Customer: "Shipping: ApSo spol. s r.o., Tomas Ruzicka V Lipkach 894/6, Hradce Kralove Czech republic tomas.ruzicka@apso.cz +420604915369"
AI Manager (internal): "Still missing for RMA package: typed Serial Number (exact as printed), ZIP code for the shipping address"

RESPONSE_DELAYS.reasoning: The structured metrics show a slow initial response and a very long overall resolution time, indicating significant delays in handling/closure. Even if some time was waiting on customer input, the ticket remained open/unsolved for weeks per the CSV.

PREMATURE_CLOSURE.reasoning: The ticket is marked solved/closed in the CSV, but the visible conversation focuses on requesting more diagnostics/RMA info and does not show a clear confirmation of resolution or RMA completion. Given the recurring outages on an RMA replacement device, closure without documented resolution suggests possible premature closure (uncertain due to truncated later interactions).

P1_SEV1_MISHANDLING.reasoning: The customer reports loss of WAN and VPN access (business outage) at a remote site on a recently replaced hardware unit, but support primarily followed a routine RMA info-gathering and diagnostic checklist (video, factory reset/system recovery) rather than showing clear incident-style triage or immediate containment steps. Although the ticket was marked URGENT, the handling still appears process-heavy relative to the described impact.
evidence: Customer: "The webUI was unresponsive, WAN was not working - no VPN connection from our side and clients in the office could not reach the internet via WAN."
AI Manager (internal): "Marked ticket as URGENT."
AI Manager (public): "please perform ... 1) Run the Kerio Control hardware diagnostic tool ... 2) ... perform a factory reset and full system recovery"
